Award.AwardTitle: EFRI-SEED 2015 Workshop and MRS Symposium Travel: Innovating Next Generation Building Materials that Adapt and Respond to Users and the Environment

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This symposium and associated workshop will bring together architects, scientists and engineers who are pioneering new models for collaboration towards the innovation of next generation building materials that adapt and respond to users and the environment. Importantly, this symposium will feature an associated workshop that will bring together for the first time the architects who are a part of the ten winning NSF Emerging Frontiers for Research Innovation Program (EFRI), Science of Energy and Environmental Design (SEED): Engineering Sustainable Buildings, projects across the US. The EFRI-SEED principal investigators will discuss the successes and failures of these new collaborative models and next steps for implementing design research infrastructure in our architecture schools to ensure that this type of cutting edge research has longevity and long-term impact upon the field of sustainable design. Deans and Chairs at participating schools will be invited to the workshop.

Although there have been tremendous innovations in design, material sciences, bio and information technologies, and engineering, direct interactions and collaborations between scientists, architects and engineers are rare. Scientists, engineers and architects all share the need to comprehend key social, environmental and technological issues associated with the buildings we live and work in. The research is considered particularly important as it represents a fusion of disciplines working towards a common goal for the public interest. The intent is that research of this nature will allow scientists, engineers and designers to engage the public in the excitement of new technologies and the basic research that bears them out, as well as, offering an effective tool to recruit and train students. This symposium provides a singular opportunity for intellectual exchange between investigators pioneering this frontier and to involve next generation researchers in this discussion.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Symposium NN, Between Architecture, Science and Engineering - Innovating next generation materials for sustainable building design, was held during the 2015 Materials Research Society (MRS) Spring Meeting.  In 2010, NSF solicited transformative research proposals that (for the first time) would include architects in the call for sustainable engineering design as part of the Emerging Frontiers for Research Innovation Program. This historical call created a singular opportunity for architects to collaborate with scientists and engineers within the framework of a typical long-term investigation. This symposium also featured an associated workshop that brought together (for the first time) the architects that are a part of the 10 winning project proposals across the United States.  Participants discussed the succeses and failures of these new collaborative models and next steps for implementing design research infrastructure in our architecture schools to ensure that this type of cutting-edge research has longevity and long-term impact upon the field of sustainable design.

This research is considered particulary important as it represents a fusion of disciplines working towards a common goal for the public interest.  The hope is that research of this nature will allow scientists, engineers and designers to engage the public in the excitement of new technologies and the basic research that bears them out, as well as offering an effective tool to recruit and train students.  This symposium provided a singular opportunity for intellectual exchange across investigators pioneering this frontier and to involve next-generation researchers in this discussion.

The NN MRS session addressed specifically the role of material innovation based in integrative models of sustainability, adaptation, change and performance in buildings through presentations and dialogues between architects and scientists with leading research in this frontier. The MRS session discussion was intersected to the EFRI-SEED dialogues of the encumbrances and successes encountered by the EFRI investigators across the interdisciplinary processes faced by each team.  Findings of the symposium indicate that the preparation of the next-generation materials and workforce will call for increase hybrid Studio-Lab models which will involve shared curricular modifications and infrastructure for the convergence of architecture, science and engineering. Symposium speakers offered specific recommendations aiming at the revision of the undergraduate and graduate curricula including increased technological fluency skills in material processing and simulation from the nano to the building scale. To enable these critical transformations where the role of design is pivotal in transformative research in building performance requires establishing robust funding platforms that integrate science, engineering and architecture. The generation of new knowledge in this field bears not only intellectual impact through the generation of new knowledge and technology in multiscale design of the built environment, but since its rooted in solving real world environmental and health challenges, it bears critical overall impact for society.
